transcript.text: It’s not enough to avoid conflicts of interest – we also must avoid even the appearance of a conflict. Let’s review a better way to handle these situations.

contentText.text: You've just heard from some people who perceived a conflict of interest. How could these situations have been handled better?

instructionText.text: Select each heading to learn more.
Click on Next (bottom right arrow) to continue.

tabText.text: Carter perceives a conflict of interest because Anna’s brother works in HR and she was awarded a job that Carter had applied for.

Before Anna was ever up for a promotion, she and her brother both should have notified the company of the potential conflict. Her brother could have removed himself from any decisions related to Anna’s role at Johnson Controls. This would have helped ensure that the best candidate was selected for the promotion and ensure there was no cause for speculation about having an unbiased selection process.
A vendor perceives a conflict of interest because he has learned about a friendship between his contact and the other vendor selected for the job.
It’s possible it was acceptable for John’s friend’s company to bid for work with Johnson Controls, and to win the bid if they are the best choice.
However, John should have notified the company of his conflict, and the vendor selection should have been managed by someone who didn’t have a personal interest in helping a specific vendor.
A client perceives a potential conflict because a Johnson Controls employee referred him to a company he later learned she had a personal investment in.
Vinca should have never put herself or Johnson Controls in this position.

She has a responsibility to Johnson Controls to share any opportunities that arise during her work – and she certainly can’t take advantage of these opportunities to benefit herself. Vinca should not be working or investing in a company that could find itself competing with Johnson Controls.
